facts.text: Writ Petition NO. 845 of 1973 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition NO. 845 of 1973. Under Art 32 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner is a citizen of India.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, a citizen of India, has filed this habeas companypus petition challenging order of his detention

facts.text: Detention order dated 24-11-1972 passed under Section 5 clause (a) of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: challenging order of his detention, dated 24-11-1172 passed under Section 5 clause  a  of Maintenance of Internal Security. Act, 1971

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on 20-11-1972.

anchor.surface_text: It appear that the petitioner was actually arrested on 20-11-1972 and that the detention order was passed subsequently on 24-11-1972

facts.text: Detention order served on petitioner on 24-11-1972 with sole ground of detention.

anchor.surface_text: and, on that very date, the petitioner was served with the document companytaining sole ground of detention

facts.text: On 11-10-72 at about 01.55 hrs., petitioner along with associates armed with bombs and weapons victimised wagon No. NR 17393 and committed theft of tea chests from goods train near Booster Sub-station of Dum Dum Jn. R.S.

anchor.surface_text: That on 11-10-72 at about 01.55 hrs., you along with your associates, being armed with bombs and other weapons, victimised wagon No. NR 17393 Ex Bro to KPD attached to running goods train in EC 249 DN near the Booster Sub- station of Dum Dum Jn. R S

facts.text: Train guard and RPF party challenged petitioner and associates, who hurled bombs towards RPF; RPF RK Sitaram Rai fired one round in self defence; petitioner and associates fled leaving three chests of tea at the P.O.

anchor.surface_text: Train guard RPF party challenged you and your associates when you hurled bombs towards the RPF party. RPF RK Sitaram Rai fired one round in self defence when you and your associates fled away leaving behind three chests of tea at the P.O.

facts.text: Petitioner's action caused disruption of train service for a considerable time and affected supplies and services.

anchor.surface_text: Your action caused disruption of train service for a companysiderable time and affected supplies and services, You have thus acted in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity.

facts.text: Only one ground of detention provided to petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: After giving what is marked as ground number 1 only, implying thereby that there was numberother ground of detention

facts.text: Petitioner informed he may make representation to State Government against detention order.

anchor.surface_text: You are hereby informed that you may make a representation to the State Government against the detention order and that such representation shall be addressed to the Assistant Secretary Home  Special  Department, Government of West Bengal

facts.text: Case to be placed before Advisory Board within thirty days from date of detention under Section 10 of MISA.

anchor.surface_text: Under Section 10 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  Act 26 of 1971.  your case shall be placed before Advisory Board within thirty days from the date of your detention under the order.

facts.text: Petitioner may be heard in person by Advisory Board under Section 11 of MISA if desired.

anchor.surface_text: You are also informed that under Section 11 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  Act 26 of 1971  the Advisory Board. shall if you desire to be so heard, hear you in person

facts.text: Annexure to affidavit by Special Secretary, Home Dept, Govt of West Bengal (District Magistrate at time) includes copy of petitioner's representation to Government.

anchor.surface_text: An annexure to the affidavit filed by a Special Secretary in the, Home Department of the Government of West Bengal, who was the District Magistrate companycerned when the impugned detention order was made against the petitioner,is a companyy of the petitioners representation

facts.text: Petitioner asserts allegations against him are absolutely untrue.

anchor.surface_text: In the representation as Well as in the petition before us, the petitioner asserts that the allegations against him are absolutely untrue

facts.text: Petitioner states it is palpably false to allege he committed theft from a running wagon and fled leaving tea chests at P.O.

anchor.surface_text: In his application to this Court he states that it is palpably false and impracticable to allege that the petitioner with some associate companymitted theft of some tea chests from a running, wagon and that he fled When challenged, leaving behind three chests of tea at the P.O

facts.text: Petitioner submitted there was no evidence he was identified as participator in the incident.

anchor.surface_text: In his representation to the Government, the petitioner had submitted that there was numberevidence that he was identified by anybody as a participator in the incident.

facts.text: Affidavit in opposition states goods train came to a stop due to traffic restriction, not actually running.

anchor.surface_text: In the affidavit in opposition to the petition, the official companycerned, who had passed the detention order, stated The running goods train as stated therein actually means a goods train which bad companye to a stop due to traffic restriction

facts.text: Affidavit states petitioner is a notorious wagon breaker operating near Dum Dum Junction Railway Station.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit also companytained the statement It appears from the records that the petitioner is a numberorious wagon breaker operating near Dum Dum Junction Railway Station.

facts.text: No mention in record that petitioner was notorious wagon breaker.

anchor.surface_text: We were unable to find any mention in this record that the petitioner was a numberorious wagon breaker.

facts.text: Record describes modus operandi of gang of thieves on passenger trains, activities commenced after 11-10-1972.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, we found a description there of the modus operandi of a gang of thieves operating on passenger trains which used to deprive the passengers of their trunks and other goods ... It is mentioned there that the activities of this gang companymenced after the incident of 11-10-1972.

facts.text: Incriminating articles recovered from members of gang including petitioner; prosecutions pending against them.

anchor.surface_text: it is also mentioned there that a number of incriminating articles were recovered from members of this gang of thieves including the petitioner and that prosecutions were pending against them.

facts.text: Incident of 11-10-1972 mentioned in record but no indication how District Magistrate knew petitioner was member of gang concerned.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the incident which occured at about 2 a.m. company11-10-1972, forming the ground of detention, is also mentioned in the record but, there is numberindication as to how any information whatsoever came to the District Magistrate

facts.text: Petitioner asserts he was arrested on 20-10-1972 for reasons not disclosed, and detention ordered when no evidence found.

anchor.surface_text: This makes the petitioners assertion, that be, was number only, arrested on 20-10-1972 for reasons number disclosed to him, but, when sufficient evidence companyld number be found against him by the local officials, a, detention order was made

facts.text: Ground of detention vague as to meaning of 'P.O.'

anchor.surface_text: Be that as it may, it is difficult to understand what is meant by the P.O.

facts.text: Matters not communicated to petitioner taken into account in ordering detention.

anchor.surface_text: But, as indicated above, we have found that matters which were never companymunicated to the petitioner also appear to have been taken into account while ordering the detention of the petitioner.
